1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Studies associated with prevention program elements such as PHAs, incident investigation, management of change, and compliance audits are regularly conducted at the Marks Site to verify designs and to identify potential hazards.  Recommendations may be developed as a result of these studies and as a result of equipment inspections, safety meetings, review of industry experience, technology improvements, and employee suggestions.  Once formulated, recommendations are reviewed, and corresponding action items are developed. All actions are tracked and routinely reviewed by senior management.

1.3.2.1 PHA and LOPA Methodology
General
Initial PHAs and LOPAs for the Marks facility were conducted using a mixture of What-If, Checklist, What-If/Checklist, and Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) methodologies to determine and evaluate the hazards of the covered processes.  Future PHAs and LOPAs will also utilize acceptable PHA methodologies which include the following:
-What-If
-Checklist
-What-If/Checklist
-Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP)
-Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)
-Fault Tree Analysis

The PHA and LOPA methodology used shall be appropriate for the complexity of the process. Typically, for new projects HAZOP or What-If PHA methodology is appropriate.  For PHAs conducted as part of the MOC process, typically What If, Checklist, or What-If/Checklist PHA methodology is appropriate.  The Process Safety Program Manager can provide guidance on appropriate PHA methodology as needed.

-The hazards of the process.
-Any previous incident with potential for catastrophic consequences in the workplace.
-Engineering/administrative controls related to hazards.

-Facility siting (the location of various components within the facility).
-Human factors.
-Qualitative evaluation of possible safety/health effects on employees stemming from control failures.

1.3.2 Process Hazard Analysis
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Standard, (RNG-ALL-P2003 Process hazard Analysis) [2] and Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) Standard (RNG-ALL-P2005 Layer of Protection Analysis) [3], establishes the program for assessing the hazards of covered process operations at the Marks Site.  By systematically examining each covered process and identifying the hazards associated with operation of the process, the Marks site has been able to plan for and will take appropriate actions to improve the safety of our employees, contractors, and visitors, the community, and the environment.
PHAs and LOPAs have been conducted for all process operations at the Marks facility covered by standards RNG-ALL-P2003 Process hazard Analysis [2] and RNG-ALL-P2005 Layer of Protection Analysis [3].  PHAs/LOPAs are conducted in a manner appropriate to the complexity of the process.  The objectives of the PHAs/LOPAs are the following:
-To identify the hazards of the process
-To identify credible human error and/or equipment failures that could lead to accidental release
-To evaluate the likelihood and severity of potential scenarios
-To determine if existing safeguards (engineering and/or administrative controls) are adequate
-Where existing safeguards are inadequate, identify additional safeguards that should be considered 

Per EPA RMP requirements, all initial PHAs/LOPAs will be conducted prior to facility startup and will be revalidated every 5 years.  In addition, to the extent possible, scheduling priority of future revalidation PHAs/LOPAs should be based on the extent of the process hazards, number of potentially affected employees, and age and operating history for the involved units.

The Marks RNG, LLC commercial process involves the use of cow manure to create RNG. As commercial process operations at the Marks site contain > 10,000 pounds of biogas in storage and in the interconnected process, the commercial process at the Marks site is covered by EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule. The quantity of processed RNG, which is over 99% methane, in storage and in the interconnected process at the Marks site is less < 10,000 pounds. The characteristics and hazards of methane, the covered flammable substance in the biogas mixture, are described in the following section (Section 1.2.3).
1.2.3 Characteristics and Hazards of Methane and Safeguards Applied
Methane is a colorless and odorless gas or a liquid under pressure. It is used as a light source and fuel, and is the major gas present in Natural Gas and Renewable Natural Gas. Methane is flammable and an explosion hazard. Liquefied methane floats on water and boils. The vapor cloud produced is flammable. 

To minimize the potential for leakage of methane at Marks site, inherently safe design, pressure relief systems, Basic Process Control System (BPCS) interlocks, Safety Instrumented System (SIS) interlocks, administrative controls, and extensive operator training have been included.  To minimize the potential for fire should methane leakage occur, flammable gas detectors have been located throughout process operations at Marks.  These flammable gas detectors have been equipped with alarms to the control room as well as local audible and visual alarms set at no greater than 10% of the lower explosive limit (LEL) indoors and no greater than 20% LEL outdoors, to provide notification well before leakage reaches the flammable/explosive range. 1.2	Description of the Marks Site, Site Processes, and Prioritization of EHS

1.2.1 Description of the Physical Site
The Marks Site is located at 6314 Cannan Rd, Lowville, in Lewis, County, New York.  It is located approximately 90 miles northeast of Syracuse, New York and is adjacent to the Marks Dairy. 
The Marks site is comprised of generally level terrain. Per FEMA Flood Insurance Rate Map number 360372B, this site is in Flood Zone C, an area outside the 500-year floodplain within an area of 0.2 percent annual chance of flood hazard. 
Highway access to the Marks site is convenient over national highways, state routes and county roads.  Access to this site will be from State Rte 12 Hwy.


1.2.2 Description of Site Processes and Stationary Source
The process of producing pipeline quality RNG begins with cow manure that is collected from farms, processed, and fed into anaerobic digesters. Within the anaerobic digester, the manure is then broken down by microbes and creates raw biogas, which is a mixture of methane, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, oxygen, water, and hydrogen sulfide. 1.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1 Accidental Release Prevention, Emergency Response, and Commitment to EHS at the Marks RNG, LLC Site
The Marks site is operated by Marks RNG, LLC whos parent company is SJI RNG DevCo, LLC. SJI RNG DevCo, LLC is working with REV LNG, LLC (REV), who is a full-service supplier of Liquified Natural Gas (LNG), Compressed Natural Gas (CNG), and Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) based in Victor, New York. Since the companys inception in 2013, REV has emerged as a leading provider of mobile gas solutions including transportation logistics, marine, mobile fuel solutions, and project development. Having safely sourced and delivered thousands of LNG loads to a variety of markets including Public Utilities, Renewable Gas projects, and Exploration and Production Companies, REV is focused on providing best-in-class turnkey mobile energy service with a focus on safety and environmental stewardship. 
REV specializes in the development and transportation of renewable natural gas (RNG), liquified natural gas (LNG) and compressed natural gas (CNG) in North America. Over the last few years, REV has become one of the countrys leading developers of RNG projects through capturing, cleaning and converting bio-methane to RNG. REV acquired the rights to build anaerobic digesters on dairy farms to produce RNG for injection into natural gas pipelines; REV then sources, supplies and transports RNG to utilities through ownership of mobile tankers, decompression and vaporization assets to ensure safe, firm and dependable service.
REV is committed to being a responsible member of any community
